data.title: filterText seems ignored in autocompletion
data.body: This is a follow-up on https://github.com/redhat-developer/vscode-java/issues/187 In vscode-java, completion item labels are formatted as `type - package`, because we find it more [user friendly](https://github.com/redhat-developer/vscode-java/issues/47) to display the package immediately, instead of relying on selecting the item to show the details content. This is how all Java IDEs present autocompletion results anyway. Because the label contain spaces, autocompletion doesn't stop when typing a space, which is [annoying](https://github.com/redhat-developer/vscode-java/issues/187). So we tried using [filterText](https://github.com/Microsoft/language-server-protocol/blob/master/versions/protocol-2-x.md#completion-request) instead, as the protocol states: ```js /** * A string that should be used when filtering a set of * completion items. When `falsy` the label is used. */ filterText?: string; ``` So our completionItems now look like ```json { "label": "Map - java.util", "kind": 7, "sortText": "zzzzzzzbge", "filterText": "Map", "data": { "decl_signature": "Ljava.util.Map;", "pid": "62", "rid": "6", "uri": "file:/Users/fbricon/Dev/vertx-game-server/src/main/java/com/redhat/middleware/keynote/GameUtils.java" } }, ``` But vscode still seems to filter using the label ![may-15-2017 13-24-42](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/148698/26070249/ef46c688-3971-11e7-8694-0a59fc6d7cea.gif) To which @jrieken replied: Yeah, we always try with the label first and use the filter text only when not matching the label. Mostly because when using the filter text we cannot render the blue highlights. But it could be considered a bug on our side Would it be possible to decouple filtering from highlighting here?

data.title: resourceLangId == 'azcli' not matching untitled file
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code - Insiders 1.13.0-insider (2fbc979be2bd0fec6dc2af713367b2930f818121, 2017-05-17T08:10:06.896Z)
- OS Version: Darwin x64 15.6.0
- Extensions: Many

The Azure CLI extension is using `resourceLangId == 'azcli'` to scope keybindings and menu items to the language id it contributes. That works as expected in saved files, but does not work (no menu items, no keybindings) in an untitled file with language mode 'azcli'.

https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode-azurecli/blob/master/package.json#L87

data.title: Copy and Paste are not working
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

- VSCode Version: 
LOL --I'd copy and paste my details from the VSCode About menu, but Copy and Paste doesn't work on that window.

- OS Version: Win10 Ent

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Use Powershell (maybe other shells too) in VS Code
2. Try to copy something
3. Try to paste it somewhere else.
4. Fail

I have no idea what's going on here. I've tried "just selecting it," which often works in a lot of terminals. I've tried `shift + c`, some one on SO said you have to hit `enter` after you select it. There seems to be no rhyme or reason to how copy and paste works in windows in general.

If I'm running something that doesn't exit and for instance would kill that process with `ctrl + c.` I would use `ctrl + shift + c.` 

I have no idea what is going on the behavior is non-deterministic. Sometimes it works sometimes it doesn't. I just want to be able to copy text from my logs please.

Please help.

data.title: Autocompletion breaks tab/snippet workflow
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Insiders 1.13, 3bb9b5314ef50bd8225aba0565cadc6ca19bc821, 2017-05-18T06:18:32.269Z
- OS Version: MacOS Sierra 10.12.4

Steps to Reproduce:

1. open a .ts file
2. type func| select function template
3. start typing log, code assist kicks in, press tab
4. press tab to go to next placeholder -> tab is inserted instead

This becomes really inconvenient when using the Java language support, with a template like `public ${1:type} ${2:name}($3)`, as you really want to leverage code assist for the 1st placeholder (class type), but then tab jumping is completely broken.

data.title: New theme order in quick open breaks muscle memory
data.body:
F1 > type 'theme'
Notice that there is a new hit which is ranked N#1
This is a problem becuase it breaks people's muscle memory. I personally change a theme once per day at least and for doing that I just quickly do F1 'theme' and press enter without looking and I always get the wrong option.
Could we rename the theme generator to be worse ranked?

![screen shot 2017-05-18 at 10 04 51](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1926584/26192331/82e312de-3bb1-11e7-8f02-c0905045f6a7.png)

data.title: Autocomplete triggers on new class method with public identifier
data.body:

- VSCode Version: 1.12.2 (1.12.2)
- OS Version: macOS Sierra Version 10.12.5 (16F73)

Steps to Reproduce:

1.
```
let something;
class Test {
}
```
2. In class Test type "some()" it works as expected. But if you write "public some()" it autocompletes
```
let something;
class Test {
	some() // wrote "some()" here
	public something() // wrote "public some()" here
}

```

data.title: Find a way to prevent further breakage of build due to `let` in .js files
data.body:
Our build breaks way too often in the magnification step because we keep adding syntax not supported by Uglify2 to our JavaScript files. This often goes unnoticed until the integration builds run, which usually lands on someone's feet by surprise. We need to fix this ASAP.

Options:

- upgrade to https://www.npmjs.com/package/uglify-es would it work?
- create eslint rules to prevent this from happening

These are the affected files:

```
vscode master → ls src/**/*.js | grep -v "/test/"
src/bootstrap-amd.js
src/bootstrap.js
src/buildfile.js
src/cli.js
src/main.js
src/paths.js
src/vs/base/common/marked/marked.js
src/vs/base/common/marked/raw.marked.js
src/vs/base/common/winjs.base.js
src/vs/base/common/winjs.base.raw.js
src/vs/base/node/startupTimers.js
src/vs/base/node/stdForkStart.js
src/vs/code/buildfile.js
src/vs/code/electron-browser/sharedProcess.js
src/vs/css.js
src/vs/loader.js
src/vs/nls.js
src/vs/workbench/buildfile.js
src/vs/workbench/electron-browser/bootstrap/index.js
src/vs/workbench/electron-browser/workbench.main.nls.js
src/vs/workbench/parts/html/browser/webview-pre.js
src/vs/workbench/parts/terminal/electron-browser/terminalProcess.js
```

You can validate it by running `gulp minify-vscode`.

cc @Microsoft/vscode If someone has cycles this iteration please take this issue and fix it.

- VSCode Version: Version 1.12.2 (1.12.2)
- OS Version: MAC OS X EL Capitan 10.11.6

For new users of VSCode (I'm of cause a loyal VSCode user), some of them may find it confusing when clicking bottom-right status bar buttons (Spaces: 2, UTF-8, etc.), they may think nothing happens on the clicking if they don't notice that a Command Palette drops down from top of the screen, the problem is the click point is far away from the position of visual feedbacks. 

Will it help if it adds an animation when clicking those buttons, e.g. a box shape slides from bottom-right to top-middle? So that user's attention would be guided to the Command Palette.

Thanks.

data.title: Extension API FileSystemWatcher is a bit odd
data.body:
When I call ```createFileSystemWatcher```, I can tell it to ignore create, change and/or delete events. The ```FileSystemWatcher``` then have 3 read only properties that just tells me which parameters I used to create it, that does not seem very useful and looks like an internal implementation detail that have leaked into the public API. If there is some argument for keeping them, then I suspect that the same argument could be used for the ```globPattern```.

I then have to set a callback for each of the events - why would I tell the ```FileSystemWatcher``` to ignore an event and then provide a callback for it or tell it not to ignore an event and then not provide a callback for that event?

To encourage extension developers to only watch what they need, I think it would be better if you had to opt in to which events you want to watch. I assume that is also the reason for having the ```globPattern``` in the first place.

Adding ```watchXxxxxxEvents``` properties and deprecate the ```ignoreXxxxxxEvents``` might also be a way to fix #26851 in a non-breaking way. Making them read+write would also be useful for temporarily pausing the watcher without having to completely tear down and re-create the watcher. It is easy to forget to call ```dispose()```, which is probably bad if you need to pause it often.

The callback only get a ```vscode.Uri``` parameter, so if I'm only interested in monitoring when a directory is created or deleted, then for create events, I have to make a ```fs.stat(e.fsPath).isDirectory()``` call and for deletes, I have to keep a list of existing directories, so I can lookup if it is directory. If I'm only interested in changed files, then I have a similar problem.

I think a better interface would be to have just one callback that get the type of change (create, change, rename, delete), the type of object changed (file, directory) and the Uri.

I know that detecting renames is hard, especially in a way that works cross platform, but it could be really useful and I think that is actually a good reason for why it should be in the VS Code core, so extension developers have to worry less about cross platform issues - not everybody have access to all platforms.

data.title: Update environmentService.ts to enable ENV defined extenstions-dir

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
This update allows VS Code users to define the desired extensions directory by means of an environment variable "vscode_config_ext", instead of having to rely on the command-line arguments.  By providing a path to the extensions directory in an environment variable, VS Code is able to have a system or user defined extensions directory that does not require a wrapper script to launch code for the settings to take effect.  This solution is similar to the npm ENV variable solution "npm_config_cache".

This is 1/2 of the solution for providing a portable solution to remove VS Code from the Windows roaming profile.

data.title: Update paths.js to allow use of ENV variable as alternative to cmd args

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
…override for userDataPath

This patch allows defining the environment variable "vscode_config_prefix" as a global default, instead of relying on command line arguments.  The solution is similar to NPM's npm_config_prefix environment variable.  if defined, APPDATA, XDG_CONFIG_HOME, and other solutions are ignored for determining the path value.  This is 1/2 the solution to removing the user data from the Windows roaming profile.
